author: Josh F
title: Scale-UP Cardano's Community Hubs
description: How do we encourage Local Community Hubs to drive adoption and awareness of Cardano in the next 6 months?

assessments.note: In Fund4 a very similar challenge has been launched (Local Community Centers). This challenge could be a continuation based on the results from Fund4 challenge. It is very important to bring non-english speakers into Catalyst and the proposal is very relevant. Some hubs already exist, so maybe this continuation should be considered in the budget rationale as well as the creation of new hubs.

As the "world's operating system", Cardano needs to make headway into many communities soon. This proposal indirectly addresses the silo mentality that is prevalent in many of our blockchain competitors. To facilitate real world applications and solve the world's needs, this is an essential proposal to tap into the wisdom of the people that have no access to Cardano yet.
It is essential to the Cardano mission to educate many people on blockchain technology and ADA in a decentralised manner in order to enable inclusive and diverse participation.

The idea is great, but unfortunately the proposal is missing lot of data. I would prefer too see what will be the first languages targeted, why and an actual time plan about each of them. Team contents and overall project time plan would be also necessary if I would need to make a decision about. There is lot of potential in it and it would be good to work through more a bit.
assessments.reply: That's why we have proposals, for them give thier own project time plans and languages targeted and get voted on if the community believes in thier approach. The challenge is not meant to be area or language specific.

assessments.note: With the community hubs being set up around the African continent and other parts of the world, it is difficult to give this challenge setting a priority. LCCs that will be funded in Fund4 will give us a good understanding of their effectiveness and progress. Having this data will allow the community to decide whether or not to continue funding these hubs for future grows, or if self-sustainability should be demanded. Furthermore, stating that Cardano is building technology for the blockchain-savvy population only is misguiding.  Current Cardano Ambassadors serve a good role of foot soldiers who can educate their own communities and continue aiding to the organic growth of the ecosystem.
assessments.reply: The Fund 4 LLC was $50k, is this adequate to give a fair assessment for hubs? That's what this proposal addresses

assessments.note: I am very happy to review a proposal that I find well thought out and presented. Yes, the proposal aligns very well with Cardano's mission, vision, community, and values, and its technical capabilities and potentialities. In my view, the proposal aligns with the necessity and the goal to reach people generously with a life-transforming technology in their own terms and empowering them to steward the technology and their communities. Thank you for presenting this.
Whilst this is important, I am not sure this qualifies as a challenge. Also how will 0 hubs in 10 places make a significant impact for Cardano globally?

This challenge is fully aligned with Cardano's mission. At Fund4 the Cardano Foundation had funded a similar challenge as a pilot and the community created promising proposals where it was possible to see the potential of this concept. It is extremely important that Cardano's regional hubs exist in different locations around the world for Cardano to be disseminated in different cultures and languages and thereby achieve greater adoption, which is one of Cardano's greatest objectives.

I like this idea and think it is suited to a challenge that can elicit many varied proposals. Real world adoption means and requires real world engagement presenting people with solutions to their real world problems. This can enable cross fertilisation of ideas as well as the dissemination of use cases and growth of different elements of the ecosystem.
Catalyst community is capable of developing such hubs, and some of them already exist. The challenge is completely feasible and will probably have many proposals submitted.

The rationale for this is hopefully obvious. The Catalyst and greater Cardano community has showcased positive outreach and bringing people together. This is a more focused effort  of the ongoing work.

While the cardano community consists of many people in different countries with a good collective knowledge doeaking many different languages, it will be quite a big challenge to manage these skills in a way that all hubs can benefit from them in a sufficient manner, especially at the low budget allocated. In general, the budget allocated will nit be enough to create 10+ community hubs being equipped to performing all those tasks.

I think measuring the amount of hubs and people joined is once part of the story. The hub quality and content shall get at least the same focus. How to would be the community activity tracked and continuously followed up. Setting up the hubs seems just a fraction of the overall story and if the funds will be used only for that it won't last long. Try to focus a bit on a longer time plan and future upscaling, maintenance and continuous adaptation aspects as well.
assessments.reply: There doesnt need to be a specific number of hubs set up, that's an incomplete reading. A good project could apply for the whole fund. How sustainable they are will depend on thier proposal and not the challenge outline.

assessments.note: Data from previous funds points to the fact that people are willing and eager to drive the adoption and education to further promote Cardano. It would be worthwhile to give these projects a fair chance of proving their worth and then decide whether or not it is feasible to further invest in this approach. At the moment, there are many different outlets for Cardano to propagate organically.

From my personal expertise and life experience, I believe the proposal is even more feasible than the author has been able to illustrate. In the very short space of the proposal and the attachments provided, the author has clearly made me believe that the proposal is feasible, nevertheless, they could have done (or could do in the future) a better job at demonstrating that the experience to successfully execute this project exists out there in the world and that they have enough mastery of it to channel it for the particular case of Cardano. To greatly increase the potential for success of the proposal I would suggest two things. 1) That the proposal is focused on piloting a relatively small, well-known, and well-supported (regarding infrastructure) region. And, 2) That instead of creating Hubs 'de Novo' (new, from scratch, etc.), the proposal focuses on refurbishing existing hubs as Carnano Hubs. For the first point, I suggest the authors take an area they know well and propose to build the ten hubs there as a demonstration (this could be in a province in India, a city in Africa, or a small natural region in Latin America). It should be a region where there is electricity, internet, a minimal tradition of computers' use, stable government, etc. For the second point, I suggest that in such a region they can find existing institutions that can be transformed into Cardano Hubs, for example, a public school or a private school, a public library. In Latin America, we have places like cultural centers that function as meeting and teaching places, like Volkhochschule in Germany, places for continuous education. An even better example would be internet services (cafe internet) these are private places where the owner lends computers to the public for hours, to do government tasks (registers), homework, research or play video games. A place like this already has a technical and social infrastructure that can be harnessed for a Cardano Hub at a gain for the owner, the community, and Cardano. In the end, if the model is well documented, the experience can be shared with the broader community to be replicated widely.
I am sure the community could pull this off if they desired.
A similar challenge was created on Fund4 and there was a relevant demand, ideas for different types of local Hubs were created and the proposals created demonstrate the feasibility of the concept.
This challenge is ideally suited to the diverse global community rather than players like IOHK, and Cardano Foundation could help guide and advise.

The general metrics provided are good to evaluate the proposals, although each proposal might as well include more metrics and KPIs. Key metrics of the challenge itself could also measure the delopment of already existing community centers/hubs. Communication between different hubs and the creation of a hub network should be incentivized as well.

Reach and new (average) "users" are somewhat difficult to define and track. But the overall sentiment is clear enough. It would be up to the hosts or participants of the community hubs to (self) report; the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.
The key metrics and criteria are clearly defined and measurable. These metrics are also a good indicator if Cardano adaption in involved communities.

Creating a system of feedback and auditability is important if we are to give fair votes to competing projects. The suggested KPI and metrics are a good starting point if this challenge setting is to go forward.

The verifiability of the project is presented well enough. With the collaboration of a caring supervisor, adequate indicators can be identified for each of the stages of the process and for the results. For example, 1) the number of hubs engaged, built, or recruited. 2) the installation and start of the hubs (in construction, in training, installed, connected, online), 3) Activities scheduled in the hub, number of proponents, number of participants, computer activity, online activity, blockchain activity. 4) Subjective evaluation by the community members. It would be very important to adequately consider the involvement of social scientists to carefully and objectivelly document the last point. Finally, as mentioned in the previous point, documenting well the project would be a major requirement and that requires the involvement of someone versatile in communications (blogging, vlogging, video documentary, podcasting). Adequate documentation of the project would provide the best means for verification, as others would be able to double-check the process and reproduce it themselves.
The challenge establishes a reasonable time interval, the key metrics described are relevant and good indicators for evaluating performance and the definition of success is clear and objective.

Other criteria like proponents' capability, track record and setup need to be stipulated, and other metrics that get to the heart of whether particular proposals should be differentiated from others as to their likelihood of success are the key to helping the community decide whether particular proposals should be funded. Those are the assessments we should be trying to make a this stage I think, and getting a good set of these for each proposal would be a measure of how well the challenge had gone, in addition to the end result measurements that have been appended so far. The number of use case ideas generated from particular hub proposals, and ways to encourage generation of these, would also be useful to get proponents thinking about and measuring.

importance:
Out of the world's approximately 7.8 billion inhabitants, **6.45 billion do not speak English**.  
Living in the Western world, we forget this fact regularly, and many of us have never even considered it.  
Let's consider it now and start to **build an ecosystem that is truly global**, allowing everyone to participate to the best of their ability.  
When you **drive adoption at the ground level**, you are doing more than just 'building cool products', you are **empowering people to change their lives** in ways they could have never imagined by themselves.
